timeline.message:
fix(logstreams): introduce reference counting for log stream writers

 * on first writer creation the log appender and write buffer is created and the initial position is determined
 * on last writer closing the appender and write buffer is closed again
chore(engine): close all writers after usage

timeline.bodyText:
Out of curiosity, why call and not run if we don't return anything? Doesn't it just wrap the runnable in a Callable<Void>?
EDIT: ah, I just saw this isn't really new code, just moved. I'm still wondering why we used call there anyway 🤔
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: I moved the method yes. In the past we had the pattern if there comes an request from outside we use call for the context switch. The run method was later improve to handle this as well.
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: If using call, couldn't createWriter not just return the LogStreamWriter? Then you don't need to create an extra future. Or just switch to run; these call calls (😅) are strange to me when they return nothing.
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: I need to handle this future in the createWriter method. I can change this to #run yes.
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: We're in an actor context, no? Why do we need an atomic integer?
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Yes. At the beginning I was not 100% sure how I want to solve it. Either access the count directly, but I decided to sync with the actor. I can replace the count if you want.
replies.author: Zelldon
